instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00165: What is 820-00165? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.Q7180: What is Q7180? Inrush limiter transistor that must be told by the ISL6259 that it is safe to allow charger voltage to pass through to the computer. This needs CHGR_AGATE and CHGR_SGATE to be pulled down in order for it to close and allow voltage through to the system, current sensing failures as well as ISL6259 failures can cause this to happen. .

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS at 1V
threads.message:
WD, No Green Light

<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>:  0.8V
In diode mode reading 0.002V: short to GND
Pin2 of J6100 and <CAPACITOR>C5008</CAPACITOR> shorted to GND
Removed J6100 and <CAPACITOR>C5008</CAPACITOR>
PP3V42: 3.336V  and green light OK
trace broken between <CAPACITOR>C5001</CAPACITOR> and L5001, rebuilt:OK

PPBUS:  1V
PPBUS to GND: 3MOhms
in diode mode: 0.139V should be : compared with another board : 0.142V
remove F7140: 0.137V at pin 1 and 0.465V at pin2, doesn't seem shorted to Gnd

at <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> R17/18: 3.5Ohms and R27/28: 21.2Ohms
1:0V
2: 14.17V
3: 3.803V
4: 3.233V
5: 2.570V
6: 0V
7: 2.658V
8: 0.171V
9: 0.033V
10: SDA, pulsing OK ( burst square signal at scope )
11: SCL, pulsing OK ( burst square signal at scope )
12: 3.333V
13: 3.304V
14: 3.304V
15: 0.050V ( battery not plugged)
16: 1.300V
17: 1.020V
18: 1.020V
19: 5.035V
20: 5.020V
21: 0.027V
22: gnd
23: 1.014V
24: 4.875V
25: 5.025V
26: 1.066V
27: 1.031V
28: 1.031V

Voltage at <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> is 1.034V which means that <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> doesn't close his second fet.
normally I should read something like 13.7V on pin 1 and 13.9V on pin 2.
Is my <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> bad?
At 7180 pin 7,8,9 and 10 reading 14.15V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS at 1V
threads.message:
Change <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR>.
Once removed, check traces to its resistors.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00165</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> PPBUS at 1V
threads.message:
Hi 2Informaticos,

just to update you,  I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7180</TRANSISTOR> and rebuit some traces around <RESISTOR>R7180</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R7181</RESISTOR> and I had a nice PPBUS at 8.58V.
Unfortunately the WD went to the CPU, which directely fried when I had ppbus present, I had smoke coming out of the PCH.
Maybe directely shorted to CPU. so good to go in donor bin.

Again it was a good catch from you, and again thank you
